arcs.title: The Impossible Premise: Turning Mario 64 into a “New N64 Game”
arcs.narrative_goal: Give a global audience the emotional hook and stakes: this isn’t a novelty mod, it’s a years-long attempt to make a beloved classic feel new—on original hardware—by relentlessly rebuilding the parts that get in the way of Kaze’s taste.
topics_to_cover: Kaze’s core question in plain language: why remake a classic instead of making something modern—and why do it on real N64 constraints on purpose?
His “N64-first” identity: why ‘running on real hardware’ is a creative constraint, not a gimmick (and why 64MB matters as a psychological finish-line).
What “Return to Yoshi’s Island” means emotionally: respectful to the source, but not trapped by it—“make it feel like a real game,” not content for SM64 experts only.
The moment the project became bigger than “a level pack”: when engine rewrites, new UI, and a living overworld became non‑negotiable.
The human cost and obsession (his own words about needing to work without motivation; the ‘scaling 50 Everests’ feeling).
b_roll: Cold open: real N64 on a CRT/capture, with RTYI running smoothly; hard cut to Kaze’s workbench and code/Blender screens.
A simple visual explainer montage: ‘Original Mario 64’ → ‘RTYI’ with side-by-side feel shots (camera responsiveness, UI polish, draw distance).
Kaze’s profiler overlay footage (FPS + RSP/RDP timings) as a visual motif—numbers as the “heartbeat” of the project.
Shots of physical constraints: ROM size readouts approaching 64MB; “Expansion Pak required” screen; EverDrive/SummerCart/SC64 workflow clips.

arcs.title: Two-Person Studio: Kaze & Zeina, Marriage as a Creative Pipeline
arcs.narrative_goal: Make the process intimate and legible: the game is built inside a relationship—creative trust, real-time critique, deadlines, and family life shaping what ships.
topics_to_cover: Their collaboration loop in concrete moments: Zeina shows an animation clip; Kaze gives notes; they iterate immediately (pivot/root issues, readability).
How Zeina’s playtesting changes design (e.g., punishment softened after watching her struggle) and what that reveals about “difficulty vs frustration.”
The shift from ‘Zeina on stream’ to ‘Zeina in her own office’ and how that changes coordination and visibility.
The birth of their daughter Reyna and how the project timeline, finances, stress, and priorities visibly change afterward.
Zeina’s identity inside the project: animator/artist, story/asset contributor (message bottle, cozy village), and emotional anchor (naming Reyna on mic).
b_roll: Home footage-style verité: them working in the same room; late-night dev; Zeina’s animation files on screen; Kaze importing/previewing them in-game.
Audio of them reviewing an animation: pause, scrub, point at a pivot error; then the ‘fixed’ version in-game.
A contrast montage: pre-baby stream energy vs post-baby streams; shots of baby interruptions; the game continuing anyway.
The ‘name Reyna’ moment as an emotional pivot beat (use the stream clip audio, if licensed/available).

arcs.title: The Trust Test: Course 1 as a Promise to Players Who’ve Never Heard of ROM Hacks
arcs.narrative_goal: Show how Kaze earns (or loses) a player’s patience in the first 10 minutes—and why he treats onboarding as existential for a free project.
topics_to_cover: “Patience budget” and the ROM-hack commitment problem: why tutorials must be frictionless and immediate.
Tutorial bunnies: the shift from ‘coin nearby’ to ring-gated proof the player actually did the move (designing around human behavior, not ideal behavior).
Camera philosophy: why forced camera movement causes misinputs; the “one button → one output” mindset in feel design.
The Course 1 demo strategy: shipping one level on purpose, pairing it with a questionnaire, and using the survey to tune camera speed/options without bloating the menu.
Demo feedback turning into action: noisiness complaints, camera speed debates, what he changes vs refuses to change.
b_roll: On-screen graphic: ‘Patience Budget’ (simple meter) over footage of tutorial prompts evolving from unclear → readable billboard speech-bubbles.
Gameplay capture: the ring-gate verifying the correct move; quick cut to a player doing the wrong move and not getting the reward (clarity).
The Google Form / survey screenshots, anonymized; Kaze reading results and adjusting parameters live.
Before/after of camera controls (old hold-to-rotate vs immediate rotation) with controller inputs overlaid.

arcs.title: The Zoo That Broke the Engine: When One Laggy Level Forces a Rebuild
arcs.narrative_goal: Translate “engine work” into story: a single painful constraint becomes the catalyst for a multi-year reinvention—and the audience feels why Kaze keeps going back into the code.
topics_to_cover: The Zoo as the original catalyst: the moment performance became unacceptable and exposed foundational limits (Kaze explicitly says the Zoo triggered his optimization journey).
Hardware truth vs emulator comfort: N64-only crashes and why they’re emotionally devastating late in production.
Signature war stories with human stakes: the division-by-zero that executes anyway because of a MIPS delay slot; “I never test my code… months later a bug occurs.”
The collision rewrite as a ‘feel’ decision, not a flex: making movement consistent so players stop blaming themselves for randomness (quarter-frame dependence).

Tooling as character in the story: NEMU becoming a breakthrough for reproducing real hardware crashes; profilers revealing the game is ‘idle’ most of the frame; BVH collision as the ‘final boss’ of engine work.
A climax moment: GeoLayout bytecode / “killed pointers”—a project-wide performance win that signals the engine is becoming its own thing.
b_roll: Side-by-side: a heavy scene on real N64 before/after a key optimization (Zoo performance myth → improved reality).
A cinematic macro shot of Kaze stepping through assembly in a debugger, highlighting the offending instruction (delay slot divide).
Profiler visualization: the frame timeline showing long idle time; overlay it with Kaze reacting in real time.
Whiteboard/simple animation explainer: ‘why a collision rewrite changes how the game feels’ (no jargon, all player sensation).
Git diff / commit montage: ‘BVH complete’, ‘no more linked lists’ as chapter cards.

arcs.title: Comedy with Consequences: Oily Boily Bay and the Joy of Making a “Real Place”
arcs.narrative_goal: Let viewers fall in love with the team’s design voice: slapstick platforming that still respects the player—where every joke has to survive physics, memory, and hardware.
topics_to_cover: Why this course exists in the story: sabotage a Bowser operation; workers strike; the level changes state across missions (Act structure).
Cement footprints: how a silly gag becomes a deep systems problem (decals would explode; render-to-texture makes it possible) and why permanence matters for player expression.
Design discipline in action: cutting the oil-barrel gag because it’s cryptic; choosing to “fake physics” for glass shards because shipping matters.
The overseer Wiggler escalation: comedy as readable progression (anger grows, dialogue changes, star payoff).
Boss staging as mood: Bowser office → eerie empty protest plaza → monster appears and drags Mario into the fight (silence as a design tool).
Waiting on Zeina’s animations as a recurring production reality: the level can be “logic done” but not emotionally complete.
b_roll: Footprint mechanic close-ups: clean cement → gradually ruined → depressed Koopa easter egg trigger.
Split-screen: “real physics” vs “faked physics” glass shatter (and why the fake reads better).
A mini ‘three-act’ graphic over gameplay: Act 1 chaos → Act 2 statue destruction → Act 3 silence → boss.
Behind-the-scenes: Zeina’s Wiggler animation files; Kaze importing and triggering dialogue states in-engine.
Hardware capture of a worst-case view with FPS overlay to show the level’s scale vs the console’s limits.

arcs.title: The 64MB Wall: Music, Atmosphere, and the Cost of Ambition
arcs.narrative_goal: Make constraints visceral: the soundtrack isn’t just decoration—it’s a budget that threatens the entire project, and it forces hard choices about what the game can be.
topics_to_cover: The dawning realization: streamed music dominates ROM size (the ‘two-thirds of the ROM is music’ moment).
Badub’s role as a story force: how a track arriving mid-stream changes level atmosphere decisions (Western fog mood; overworld pack that crossfades between regions).
Why Kaze rewrites the audio engine late in development: not for bragging rights—because the existing foundation blocks new SFX and introduces bugs he can’t reason about.
The “souvenir” monetization idea (OST cartridge / box) as a compromise between sustainability and legal reality.
Emulator-only audio crashes (Project64/Parallel weirdness) and the pain of supporting players across broken setups.
b_roll: On-screen ROM size meter filling toward 64MB; cutaways to Kaze deleting tracks to reclaim space.
Music stems/layering demo: indoor/outdoor variants; overworld crossfade between regions (with a map overlay showing movement).
A “before/after” ambience montage: same scene with minimal SFX vs layered ambience after the sound engine rewrite.
Waveform/loop-point editing footage and in-game verification of seamless loops.
A visual metaphor: ‘every new song = less room for something else’ (simple budget graphic).

arcs.title: Making ‘Places,’ Not Just Challenges: Grand Sand Badland as a Living Town
arcs.narrative_goal: Show the creative leap from “platforming rooms” to “a town with vibes,” where story, audio, and comedy guide players as much as arrows do.
topics_to_cover: Kaze’s ‘placeness’ thesis: SM64 movement is legendary, but many original levels aren’t memorable places—RTYI tries to fix that.
The saloon as a storytelling machine: hidden chalky-milk backroom, overheard dialogue, readable secrets, and why NPC count is limited by writing—not just performance.
The piano Shy Guy centerpiece: diegetic music that stops when he talks; crowd stares at Mario—comedy that makes the space feel social.
Minecart chase design: preventing “degenerate solutions” (walking the rails), tuning fairness, using cutscenes to stop cheap deaths.
The High Noon / Boshi duel: building a reaction-time setpiece with accessibility in mind (input lag, adaptive easing).
Course rework honesty: Kaze admitting when a section isn’t good and restructuring it until navigation is clear.
b_roll: Cinematic walk-through of the town: signage gags, wanted posters, train station landmarks.
The piano moment: spatial audio panning demo with headphones mix vs speaker mix.
Playtest footage style reenactment: player missing the intended route → Kaze redesigning signposting.
Minecart sequence: spline path debug overlays; camera framing iteration; final polished chase.
Quickdraw duel: countdown UI iterations, camera staging, and the final ‘shoot’ moment.

arcs.title: Arts & Crafts Without a Shader: When Style Becomes a Technical Boss Fight (Course 14)
arcs.narrative_goal: Let non-technical viewers feel the absurdity and beauty of making ‘paper’ believable on a machine that can’t do modern graphics—and how taste drives engineering, not the other way around.
topics_to_cover: The craft-diorama premise: seams, tape, cardboard, glue—why the seam must be visible to sell the fantasy.
The styrofoam/‘normal map without a shader’ spiral: Kaze’s frustration, failed textures, CPU-side lighting hacks, and the eventual decision to simplify for stability/performance.
Mario Paint minigame: turning nostalgia into a playable loop (paint, flood fill without recursion, evaluator NPC, no undo because it must stay a game).
The cardboard ‘box to hell’ pull-tab: rejecting a cool-but-off-theme zipper idea; choosing the craft-authentic solution.
Performance reality: overdraw as the villain; AA cost; cutting effects when they become crash-prone.
b_roll: Macro shots of craft materials in real life (cardboard seams, tape, staples) intercut with in-game equivalents.
Time-lapse of Kaze hunting textures, failing, then prototyping the CPU-lit styrofoam highlight.
Mario Paint minigame: start with blank canvas → chaotic painting → judge interaction → star reward.
The pull-tab animation: keyframes vs in-game reveal; a “cost of one more visual flourish” overlay (RDP time).
Before/after: heavy normal-map look vs simplified stapled-paper solution, showing readability gains.

arcs.title: Final Course, Final Statement: Cosmic Colony and a Boss You Heal Instead of Kill
arcs.narrative_goal: Deliver the thematic payoff: the team isn’t just adding more—by the end they’re rewriting what ‘a Mario boss’ even means, while fighting memory, crashes, and tone boundaries.
topics_to_cover: The Course 15 identity crisis: why ‘space arcade minigames’ didn’t feel like Mario 64, and the pivot to a Shy Guy space colony that has purpose (homes, crops, water).
The mutated Yoshi / Pentapus boss: readability telegraphs (portals, lights), softlock prevention, and the narrative pivot to healing (because Yoshis are friends).
Tone boundaries: tumors replaced with mushrooms after “too disgusting” feedback—how taste edits design.
The final retro section as a love letter: many SM64 spaces coexisting; ambition repeatedly colliding with memory limits.
Speedrunner reality vs casual clarity: allowing clever skips but refusing “skip without engaging.”
b_roll: A concept-pivot montage: arcade neon prototypes → colony/station ‘placeness’ shots with landmarks.
Boss fight breakdown visuals: telegraph light → tentacle emerges → weak point breaks → Yoshi calms (color change).
A ‘tone’ comparison: tumor concept art notes vs mushroom implementation footage.
Retro section wide shot: multiple SM64 fragments visible at once; then close-ups of “fixed” UVs/readability changes.
Kaze playtesting a skip, shaking his head, and redesigning geometry to enforce the intended beat.

arcs.title: The Island That Remembers: Building a Seamless, Changing Overworld as the True Finale
arcs.narrative_goal: Answer the documentary’s central question at the scale of a world: why rebuild a classic? Because a hub can become a living island—secrets, consequences, and returns that feel like an adventure, not a menu.
topics_to_cover: The core overworld promise: ‘If you can see it, you can go there’—and why this changes how everything is designed.
Signature gates as story moments: lighthouse reveals ghost ship through fog; Wario blocks the zoo until you find the crawlspace; chained Dory unlocks travel after Bowser 1.
Overworld “events” philosophy: one-time changes that transform the island (rain flower + rebuilding houses; Pandora’s box; melon defense; swings populate with Yoshis after victory).
Seamless ambition vs N64 reality: warps as temporary scaffolding; the plan to split into many sub-levels while hiding seams.
The final overworld beats: Bone Dragon tooth → money hole gold tooth; Master Yoshi dojo hint-gag; persistent start position for ‘journey’ vibe.
b_roll: A map/diagram of the island with animated unlock paths (fog gate → lighthouse → ship).
Fog-to-white effect footage as Mario approaches the ship; then the lighthouse cutscene showing the beam move.
Wario gatekeeper blocking Mario; coin trail leading to crawlspace; first entry changes Wario’s state.
Before/after world-state: empty swings → Yoshis appear; dead island vibe → lively village.
Melon defense: cutscene start → escalating waves → melon damage feedback.
Bone Dragon encounter: tooth break → later gold-tooth befriending payoff.

arcs.title: Release Without Being Erased: Nintendo Risk, Open Source, and the Ethics of Sharing
arcs.narrative_goal: End with the real-world tension: after building something this big for free, how do you release it—without losing it to takedowns, bootleggers, or platform friction?
topics_to_cover: Kaze’s history with takedowns (videos removed repeatedly) and how that shapes his willingness to document process publicly.
Why he won’t sell cartridges (bootlegs + legal exposure), and the alternative: patch-only release, souvenir box/OST ideas.
Open-source philosophy vs timing: delaying source to avoid instant takedown/spoilers, but committing to open source so others can maintain it.
The “0% Nintendo code” campaign and the engine-only release plan: strip content, release a minimal test build, let the community audit/improve.
Emulator fragmentation as a release barrier: the temptation to ship a preconfigured emulator or recomp build so players can just play.
b_roll: Montage of removed/claimed videos (screenshots/redacted), contrasted with Kaze calmly continuing work.
Patch-only workflow visual: clean ROM → apply patch → boot; show a simple step-by-step UI mock.
Engine-only build concept: Mario in a flat field (minimal test map), as a symbolic ‘handing over the tools.’
Shots of bootleg carts/marketplace listings (if legally safe) as the shadow economy around fan work.
A closing shot: Kaze looking at the island on real hardware—then cutting to black on the question of what happens when it finally ships.
